quest_title: If \(\cfrac{a^{n+1} +b^{n+1} }{a^{n} +b^{n} } \) be the harmonic mean between \(a\) and \(b\), then the value of \(n\) is
explanation_txt:
We have

\[\cfrac{a^{n+1} +b^{n+1} }{a^{n} +b^{n} } =\cfrac{2ab}{a+b} \]

\[\Rightarrow a^{n+2} +ab^{n+1} +ba^{n+1} +b^{n+2} =2a^{n+1} b+2b^{n+1} a\]

\[\Rightarrow a^{n+1} (a-b)=b^{n+1} (a-b)\]

\[\left(\cfrac{a}{b} \right)^{n+1} =1=\left(\cfrac{a}{b} \right)^{0} \]

Hence \(n=-1\).

quest_title: The number of ways in which 10 persons can go in two boats so that there may be 5 on each boat, supposing that two particular persons will not go in the same boat is :
explanation_txt: First omit two particular persons, remaining 8 persons may be 4 in each boat. This can be done in \({}^{8} C_{4} \) ways. The two particular persons may be placed in two ways one in each boat. Therefore total number of ways are \(=2\times ^{8} C_{4} \).

quest_title: A fish at a depth of 12 cm in water is viewed by an observer on the bank of a lake. To what height the image of the fish is raised.
explanation_txt:
true depth = 12 cm

apparent depth = \(\mu_{water} \times 12\) = \(\cfrac{3}{4} \times 12\) = 9 cm

\(\therefore\) The image is raised by 12 - 9 = 3 cm.
question_plain_title: A fish at a depth of 12 cm in water is viewed by an observer on the bank of a lake. To what height the image of the fish is raised.
explanation_plain_text:
true depth = 12 cm

apparent depth = = = 9 cm

The image is raised by 12 - 9 = 3 cm.

quest_title: Rolle's theorem is not applicable to the function \(f(x)=|x|\) defined on [-1, 1] because :
explanation_txt:
\(f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{l} {-x,\, {\rm when\; - 1}\le x<0} \\ {{\rm \; \; }x,\; {\rm when}\; {\rm 0}\le x\le {\rm 1}} \end{array}\right. \)

Clearly \(f(-1)=|-1|=1=f(1) \)

But,

\[Rf'(0)={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{f(0+h)-f(0)}{h} ={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{|h|}{h} ={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{h}{h} =1\]

\[Lf'(0)={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{f(0-h)-f(0)}{h} ={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{|-h|}{-h} ={\mathop{\lim }\limits_{h\to 0}} \cfrac{h}{-h} =-1\]

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} Rf'(0)\ne Lf'(0)\]

Hence it is not differentiable on \((-1,\, \, 1)\).
question_plain_title: Rolle's theorem is not applicable to the function defined on [-1, 1] because :
explanation_plain_text:
Clearly

But,

Hence it is not differentiable on .
ans1_plain_text: is not continuous on [-1, 1]
ans2_plain_text: is not differentiable on (-1,1)

quest_title: Two charges 10 C and -5 C are separated by 12 cm apart. The work done necessary to bring them 4 cm closer is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{PE}_{1}=\cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{1}}, r_{1}=12 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(P E_{2}=\cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{2}}, r_{2}=12-4=8 \mathrm{cm}\)

Work done to bring charges from distances \(r_{1}\) to \(r_{2}\) is
\(\begin{array}{l}{W=\mathrm{PE}_{2}-\mathrm{PE}_{1}} \\ {W=\cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{1}}\left(\cfrac{1}{r_{2}}-\cfrac{1}{r_{1}}\right)} \\ {W=10 \times 5 \times 9 \times 10^{9}\left(\cfrac{1}{0.08}-\cfrac{1}{0.12}\right)}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: Two charges 10 C and -5 C are separated by 12 cm apart. The work done necessary to bring them 4 cm closer is
explanation_plain_text: Work done to bring charges from distances to is
ans1_plain_text: 3.75 10 J
ans2_plain_text: 7.5 10 J
ans3_plain_text: 7.5 10 J

quest_title: In the figure shown, there are two semicircles of radii \(r_{1} \) and \(r_{2} \) in which a current \(\textit{I}\) is flowing. The magnetic induction at the centre \(\textit{O}\) will be
explanation_txt:
The magnetic field due to both semicircular parts will be in the same direction perpendicular to the paper inwards.

And magnetic field due to linear section of wire is zero at point O.

\[\therefore B=B_{1} +B_{2} =\cfrac{\mu _{0} I}{4r_{1} } +\cfrac{\mu _{0} I}{4r_{2} } =\cfrac{\mu _{0} I}{4} \left(\cfrac{r_{1} +r_{2} }{r_{1} r_{2} } \right) \]

quest_title: Which is not true with respect to the cathode rays?
ans3_txt: Move with speed same as that of light
explanation_txt:
Cathode rays are a stream of negatively charged paticles i.e. electrons. They can be deflected by electric or magnetic field.

But electron unlike photon are not massless. Therefore, cathode rays cannot move with the speed of light.

quest_title: \(\displaystyle \lim _{x \rightarrow 64} \cfrac{\sqrt[6]{x}-2}{\sqrt[3]{x}-4}=\)
explanation_txt:
\(64 = 2^6 = 4^3\)

So the limit takes \(0/0\) form as \(x \to 64\)

Using L-Hopital's rule:

\(\begin{align} \displaystyle L &= \lim_{x \to 64} \cfrac{ \sqrt[6]{x}-2}{\sqrt[3]{x}-4} \\ & = \lim_{x \to 64} \cfrac{(1/6)x^{-5/6}}{(1/3)x^{-2/3}} \\ & = \lim_{x \to 64} \cfrac{1}{2} x ^{-1/6} \\ & = 1/4\end{align}\)

So the limit takes form as

quest_title: Three liquids of equal volume having specific heat capacity s\({}_{1}\), s\({}_{2}\) and s\({}_{3}\) at temperature \(\theta_{1}\), \({}\theta_{2}\) and \({}\theta_{3}\) and densities d\({}_{1}\), d\({}_{2}\) and d\({}_{3}\)are mixed then the final temperature of mixture will be
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{s}_{1} \theta_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{s}_{2} \theta_{2} &+\mathrm{m}_{3} \mathrm{s}_{3} \theta_{3} \\ &=\left(\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{s}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{s}_{2}+\mathrm{m}_{3} \theta_{3}\right) \theta \end{aligned}\)

\(\therefore \theta=\cfrac{d_{1} s_{1} \theta_{1}+d_{2} s_{2} \theta_{2}+d_{3} s_{3} \theta_{3}}{d_{1} s_{1}+d_{2} s_{2}+d_{3} s_{3}}\)

quest_title: Which molecules has zero dipole moment ?
explanation_txt:

so its dipole moment is zero.

quest_title: The photoelectric effect can be understood on the basis of
explanation_txt:
Line spectrum of the atom tells the energy levels of electrons inside atom and the behavior of electrons on interaction with photons. So, photoelectric effect can be understood by line spectrum of atom.

All other theories are unrelevant to photoelectric effect.

quest_title: A small object is in front of a concave spherical mirror gives an image that is real and four times the size of object. If object is moved 10cm towards mirror the virtual image of same magnification is obtained. The focal length of mirror is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)m = \( \cfrac{v}{u} \)

\(\quad\)v = 4u

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{uv}{u + v} = \cfrac{u \times 4u}{u + 4u} = \cfrac{4u}{5} \)

\(\quad\)\(2^{nd}\) case

\(\quad\)m\(\) = \( \cfrac{v}{u} \)

\(\quad\)v'\(\) = -4(u - 10)

\(\quad\)f' \(\) = \( \cfrac{u'v'}{u' + v'} = \cfrac{\left(u - 10\right)\times {-4\left(u - 10\right)}}{\left(u - 10\right) - 4\left(u - 10\right)} \)

\(\quad\) = \( \cfrac{+4\left(u - 10\right)}{3} \)

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \)\( \cfrac{4u}{5} = \cfrac{4\left(u - 10\right)}{3} \)

\(\quad\)12u = 20u - 200

\(\quad\)or, u = \( \cfrac{200}{8} \)= 25cm

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{4 \times 25}{5} \) = 20cm
question_plain_title: A small object is in front of a concave spherical mirror gives an image that is real and four times the size of object. If object is moved 10cm towards mirror the virtual image of same magnification is obtained. The focal length of mirror is
explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: Structure of ammonia is
explanation_txt: The ammonia molecule has a trigonal pyramidal shape, with nitrogen connected to the three hydrogen atoms. There are three bond pairs, and one lone pair in the central atom, nitrogen. Since the LP-BP repulsion is greater than the BP-BP, the structure is trigonal pyramidal.
question_plain_title: Structure of ammonia is
explanation_plain_text: The ammonia molecule has a trigonal pyramidal shape, with nitrogen connected to the three hydrogen atoms. There are three bond pairs, and one lone pair in the central atom, nitrogen. Since the LP-BP repulsion is greater than the BP-BP, the structure is trigonal pyramidal.

quest_title:
The standard reduction potentials at \(298\, K\)for the following half reactions are given against each

\(Zn^{2+} (aq.)+2e\)\(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\)\(Zn(s)\); - 0.762

\(Cr^{3+} (aq)+3e\)\(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\)\(Cr(s)\); - 0.740

\(2H^{+} (aq)+2e\)\(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\)\(H_{2} (g)\); 0.00

\(Fe^{3+} (aq)+e\)\(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\)\(Fe^{2+} (aq)\); 0.770

Which is the strongest reducing agent ?
explanation_txt: More negative is the reduction potential, higher will be the reducing property, \(\textit{i.e.}\) the power to give up electrons.

The standard reduction potentials at for the following half reactions are given against each

; - 0.762

; - 0.740

; 0.00

explanation_plain_text: More negative is the reduction potential, higher will be the reducing property, the power to give up electrons.
